div1.p: Sarah Ann Allen for herself and her children
Wallingford petition in Prince George Country...12

Al a Circuit court of the District of Columbia begun and held in and for the Court of Washington at the City of Washington on the fourth Monday of March being the twenty third day of the same Month in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred thirty five, and of the Independence of the united states the 59th.
In the record and proceedings of said court among others are the following touirt.
Sarah Ann Allen for herself & children agst. Joseph Wallingsford

be it remembered that heretofore tourit on the fourth day of August in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty four the said Sarah Ann Allen for herself and children by Francis S. key Esquire filed in Court here the following petition
To the Honourable the Circuit Court of the District of Columbia setting for the County of Washington.
The petition of Sarah Ann Allen for herself and her three infant children namely Eliza Jane, Julia maria &John Davy humbly showeth that she and her children

are entitled to their freedom and unjustly held and claimed by a certain Joseph Wallingford as his slaves. wherefore they pray to the discharged &c and that Subpeona may issue to the said Joseph to appear &answer hereto
Thereupon Subpoena issued as prayed for returnable to the fourth Monday of November next.

At which said fourth Monday of November March in November in the year of our Lord Term 1884 one thousand eight hundred and thirty four being the day to which said Subpoena was returnable comes here into the court the said Sarah Allen for herself and children by her said attorney; and the said Joseph Wallingford being called Defendants appears in the Court here by William L, Brent Esquire Appearance his attorney and offers to defend the said suit when and where the said Court shall take the same into consideration and for plea they say that the said petitioner are not entitled to their freedom as is alleged and of this he puts himself upon this Country, and the said petitioner in like manner to therefore let a jury thereon appear before the Court here on the fourth Monday of Novem March next by whom &c and who neither &c to recognize &c because as well &c the same day is given to the said parties then and there&c
And now tourit the said fourth Monday of March in the year of our Lord one thousand eight hundred and thirty five come again into the Court as well the Petitioners.

aforesaid as the Defendants aforesaid by their Attorneys aforesaid. Whereupon for trying the issue aforesaid between the parties aforesaid above joined to be tried by the County is ordered by the Court here that a Jury Thereon appear and twelve persons Jury being called come tourit Noble Hurdle Bennet Sewall, Anthony Smith, John F. Callan, Samuel Stetttinius, William Hebb, Henry Bradley , Alfred N Dowson, William H.Eldes, Charles Lepons, Richard J, Morsell and Azariah Huller who being duly elected empannelled and sworn to say the truth in the premises upon their Oaths do say that the said Petitioners are entitled to their freedom as they above allege- Therefore it is considered by the court here that the said Sarah Ann Allen Eliza Jane Allen, Julia Maria Allen and John Davy Allen the petitioners aforesaid be free and discharged of and from the service of the said Joseph Wallingford and that the said petitioners go thereof without day &c it is further considered by the Court here that the said Sarah Ann Allen for herself &children The petitioner aforesaid recover against the said Joseph Wallingsford the sum of twenty one dollars and three cents, for their costs and so forth and that they have thereof their execution &c
Mem: before the jurors aforesaid withdrew from the Bar of the Court

Court here the said Joseph Wallingsford by his said Attorney filed in Court here the following Bill of Exceptions tourit Defendant " On the trial of this cause the petitioner first to support the issue on their part offered in evidence A Deed of Emancipation of the said Sarah Ann Allen by Rachel Wallingsford duly executed acknowledged and recorded a copy of which is hereto annexed and marked A. (copied in page 11.) To the admission of which deed in evidence the Defendant by his counsel objected,whereupon the Petitioner Sarah Ann is the person named in and intended to the emancipation by the said deed, and that she was at the time of the execution of the said deed of emancipation residing with the said Rachel Wallingsford as her servant and that the said Rachel was then and had been for eight or nine years residing in the City of Washington in the District of Columbia and acting in all respects as a Zeme Sole, and was at times in circumstances of great poverty and distress: and that for all the time that the said Rachel resided in the said City previous to the said deed of emancipation the said Sarah Ann had been living with the said Rachel, or had been hired out by her as he slave and that the said Rachel had always received her wages where so hired, and applied to the same ti her own use and had in all respects acted as the owner of the said Negro Sarah Ann.

The Defendant then offered evidence to prove that the said Rachel Wallingsford was, at the time of the execution of the said deed, his lawful wife, and that the said Negro Sarah Ann was at the same time his slave and property.

That the said Rachel had for more than ten years before the date of the said Deed of Manumission without reasonable cause abandoned his bed and board (he then residing on his plantation in Prince George County in Maryland) and wandered about sometimes residing among her friends and neighborhood in Maryland and sometimes living by herself in Washington City in the District of Columbia. That she took with her, the said Negro Sarah Ann who was suffered by the Defendant to live with the said Rachel as her servant he not intending to deprive the said Rachel during her life of the service of the said Negro.

That the defendant repeatedly requested the said Rachel to return and live with him as his wife, which she refused to do. That in the yer 1827 he took possession of the said Negro in the City of Washington aforesaid as his slave whereupon said Rachel procured a warrant against his and caused him to be thereupon arrested and improved imprisoned in the said City of Washington for kidnapping upon which occasion the said Raphael Rachel made Oath that the said Negro Sarah Ann was her slave. That he was discharged from that arrest upon habeas corpus and agreed to leave the petitioner with his said wife Rachel if she would not harass him anymore and would give up the 120 Dollars a year which had been allowed to her for her

separate maintenance pending her suit for alimony in court in Maryland; but that she did give up the said allowance, and concealed the petitioner. That after her death the Petitioners having been committed to prison in Washington County D.C. as runaways the defendant attained a unit of Habeas Corpus from the Chief Judge of the District of Columbia , who was about to cause them to be delivered up to the defendant when they filed the present petition for freedom and thereupon the said Chief Judge refused to order them to be delivered to the Defendant unless he would give security in the usual from by way recognize for their appearance in Court to prosecute their said petition, which the Defendant was unwilling or unable to give and the petitioners still remain in custody of the Marshall of this District.

Whereupon the petitioners offered evidence to prove that the said Rachel left her said Husband and refused to live with him because he had an illicit connection with a women of ill fame whom he suffered to live on his plantation for a separate maintenance upon that ground, and that the Court allowed her 120 Dollars a year pendent lite - That the said Rachel at the time of her intermarriage with the Defendant brought him property of the value of Nine hundred Dollars including the Mother of the petitioners who was born in the Family after the marriage and had always waited on her mistress until she left her Husband, and Continued with

her after she left him. That the defendant had agreed to give to his said wife property to that amount, including the said Sarah Ann which she agreed to take, and did take and carry away upon her agreeing to acquit and discharge him from all further claims upon him for support which she did not do but that she did not receive from him anything allowed. That part of the said property consisted of single bills to the amount of three hundred and fifty Dollars which the defendant afterwards refused to pay. That she thereupon brought the aforesaid suit for a separate maintenance in the said County Court of Prince George county in Maryland which suit was pending a the time of her death in the Spring of 1884. And the Petitioners read in evidence to the court and Jury without objection by the Defendant, the petition of the said Joseph Wallingsford the Defendant to the said County Court of Prince Georges County sworn to by him on the 14th of April 1827a copy of which is hereto annexed marked B. (copied in page 12) And further offered evidence to prove that the said Petitioner Sarah Ann was at the date of the said Deed of emancipation healthy, sound in mind & body & capable by her labor to procure for herself and her children in the said Deed named sufficient food and nourishment with other necessities of life that the said children were healthy and sound mind and body upon consideration of all the matters so given in evidence by the parties as aforesaid The court permitted the aforesaid Deed of manumission to be read in evidence.

to the Jury by the Counsel for the Petitioners expressly leaving it to the Jury to say or find from the evidence whether the title of the said Rachel to the said Negro Sarah Ann at the time of the execution of the said Deed was absolute or only for the ;ife of the said Rachel: and the Court instructed the Jury that, the question was only for the life of said Rachel; and the Court instructed the Jury that, that question was open for their consideration upon all the evidence in the cause.

To which admission of the said deed in evidence, and to the said instruction to so given to the Jury the counsel for the Defendant excepts and this his bill of exceptions is signed, sealed and ordered to be enrolled

Whereupon the Defendant by his counsel prayed the court to instruct the jury that if they should believe from the evidence aforesaid (Orig. the Evidence stated in the first Bill of Exceptions) that W. Wallingsford held the petitioners by virtue of an agreement made between her and her husband without the intervention of a trustee; that said agreement is null and void and could give no power to W. Wallingsford to manumit the slaves held by virtue of such an agreement. Which instruction the Court refused to give to which refusal the Defendant by his Counsel excepted , and this his bill of exceptions is signed seal and ordered to be enrolled

The Defendant by his counsel then prayed the Court to instruct the Jury that if they should believe from the evidence aforesaid, that an agreement was entered into between Defendant & Rachel Wallingsford by which said Rachel was to have said Petitioners in lieu of being supported by him as his wife, yet if there was no covenant on the part of a trustee, or some other one capable of contradicting with said Husband that he should not be liable for the maintenance of said Rachel as his wife, the same is null- which instruction the court refused to give, to which refusal the defendant by his council excepts and this his bill of exceptions is higher sealed and ordered to be enrolled.

The Defendant by his counsel prayed Court to instruct the jury that if they should believe from the evidence aforesaid that an agreement existed between the Defendant and Mrs. Wallingford that he should transfer the Petitioners to her on condition that she should relinquish all claims to alimony against him, that then should the Jury believe from the said evidence , that she did not comply with this condition, and that she did prefer against him a subsequent claim for alimony , that the said agreement cannot be enforced against the defendant. Nor can he be deprived of any of his rights by virtue of said agreement which instruction the
Court refused to give; to which refusal the Defendant bu his Counsel excepted and this his bill of exceptions is signed, sealed & ordered to be enrolled.

The defendant then prayed the Court to instruct the Jury that if they should believe from the evidence aforesaid that the petitioners & any of them, at the time of the execution of the deed of manumission aforesaid were not able by their labor to procure for themselves sufficient food or nourishment with other necessary requisites of life then the said deed of manumission as to them, or such of them was inoperative Which instruction the court gave; and also at the prayer of the counsel for the petitioners, further instructed the Jury, that if they should believe from the said evidence mentioned were of healthy constitution and sound in mind and body, and that their Mother was capable by labor to procure to them sufficient food and nourishment with other requisite necessities of life, and did maintain them, then such children are not under incapacity intended by the Maryland law. To which last mentioned instruction the defendant by his counsel excepted this his bill of exceptions is signed sealed & ordered to be enrolled.
Manumission marked A. Referred to in page 4

To all whome it may concer. Be it remembered that I Rachel Wallingford of Washington County in the District of Columbia for diverse good causes and considerations we thereunto movings as also for and in consideration of the sum of one hundred and fifty Dollars current Money to me in hand paid, the receipt whereof I do hereby acknowledge, have released from slavery liberated manumitted and set free nd by these present do hereby release from slavery liberate mannumit and set free my Negro woman names Sarah Ann Allen aged about nineteen years and her two female children Eliza Jan Aged three years and Julia Maria aged five months, and them the said Sarah Ann Allen, Eliza Jane, and Julia Maria, I do declare to be hencefroth free manumitted and discharged from all manner of servitude or service to me my heirs execution or administrators forever.
In testimony whereof I have have hereunto set my hand and affixed my seal this eighth day of September 1820
In the presence of L.H. Wittlerger

Washington County District of Columbia Set On this eighth day of September 1826 personally appears Rachael Wallingsford part to the within instrument of writing before me the subservient Justice of the Peace in and for said County and acknowledges

the same to be her act and deed for the purposes therein mentioned and the Negro woman and her children within named to be henceforth manumitted and discharged from all services to her or toany person or persons claiming under her to be free and manumitted according to law.
Defts. Petition in Prince Georgia County Court
Petitin reffered to in page 7 as marked B.

The petition of Joseph Wallingsford Humbly represents to the Hon. Judges of the County Court of Prince Georges Country that great injustice has been done him by the interlocutory order passed in this cause at the October term of your honorable Court in 1825 in consequence of your Orator not having it in power at that time to show unto your honor the amount of his property and the extent to which he was able to pay for the separate maintenance of his wife.
Your Orator will state to your honors that it will be utterly unpossible for him to pay at the rate of $120. Per annum for the support of his wife without selling property every year for

that purpose in as much as the whole nett product of his own labour and of all of the property which he was in profession will not amount annually to near that sum, for he was only on a small plantation of poor land and two old Negroes the one an old man upwards of 60 years old with the other a woman upwards of 50 with a few horses and cattle and other small stock assist him in labor to procure a subsistence; after feeding and clothing himself and family that he has living with him, which he is bound by law and religion to support he is satisfied that all the other proceeds of his labor, land and other property could upon an average in the present times exceed $ Your Orator would further state that it is not true as alleged in the petition of the said complaint that he treated his said wife ill or drove her out of his house or home kept any other woman either white or black or yellow or of any other colour unlawfully or improperly in his house or family to the annoyance of his said wife but that his said wife became discontented and refused to live with him any longer and went off and left his bed and board without knowledge and entirely of her own will that after she had thus gone off he went to see her and told her that he wished her to come back and live with him and that if she would come back again and live with him nobody should interfere with her which she pointedly refused to do

saying that she would not to save his life, that at the time when his said wife went away she carried with her without his consent or knowledge a Negro girl about 12 years old the property of your Orator, that afterwords finding his said wife was determined to live apart from him, at her own request and by her express agreement he agreed to give her a certain sum of money, in property and cash for her future separate support amounting as your Orator believes $900. or thereabouts which she alledged that she ha dbrought with her by her marriage consisting of the aforesaid Negro Girl, $75 cash, a bed, a horse five head of cattle, 200 weight of bacon & Sundry other small articles of house hold and kitchen furniture, one single bill for $125 and oneother for 200$ amounting altogether to the aforesaid $900. Which she agreed to take as placing her in the same situation in which she was before said marriage and thereupon to aquit and discharge your Orator from all further claim upon him for support, and your Orator avers that he did actually deliver all the aforesaid money notes and property to her in pursuance of said agreement and that she carried all away, your Orator further states that after the expiration of about two years as nearly as he can now recollect his said wife became dissatisfied with her

situation and returned to his house for about three weeks would stay about two or three days at a time and go away and return and pass her time partly with your Orator and partly away after which she became offended because your Orator did not pay the aforesaid single bills, which you Orator delayed paying because he was informed and believed that he intended as soon as she should to get the money for those bills to bring a suit against him, she brought suit against your Orator in your honourable Court for a separate maintenance, the circumstances of which suit your Honors are already acquainted with as they appear upon record of your Honorable court which you can refer to, that upon you Orator being brought into you Honorable Court by an attachment he was alarmed and in that situation agreed to give his wife the sum of $2000. Including the property formerly given to her, that he might be forever rid of the necessity of supporting his said wife and being harassed by her, this however your Orator found would be ro him what would amount to his utter ruin; whereupon advised with counsel
